doc.title: China Construction Bank (0939.HK)
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/Citi/China Construction Bank 0939.HK In-line 2Q25 w record high trading gain the key positive equity dilution now fully facto_2025-08-29

passages.text: In-line 2Q25 w/ record high trading gain the key positive; equity dilution now fully factored in

CCB reported solid 1H25 PPPO growth of +3.6% y-y to RMB290.4bn, while 1H25 NPAT fell -1.4% y-y to RMB162.1bn, which is broadly in line with our preview expectation (forming c.49% of FY25 consensus estimate). 2Q25 PPPO grew strongly +14.4% y-y in 2Q25 (a notable turnaround vs. -5.8% y-y in 1Q25), thanks to surge in trading gain in 2Q. NPAT came in slower at +1.6% y-y (vs. -4.0% y-y in 1Q25), due to provision increase (+50.7% y-y). ROA/ROE were down -5bp/-82bp y-y to 0.72%/10.1% in 2Q25. CCB declared an interim DPS of RMB0.1858 for 1H25, which is down -6% y-y due to i) 1H25 earnings decline by -1.4% y-y and ii) equity dilution of -4.3% from recapitalization. 1H25 payout ratio has been kept unchanged at 30% (flat y-y).

**Key Positives** — Loan growth remains solid, +1.9% q-q/+7.9% y-y in 2Q25 (vs. +4.7% q-q/+7.9% y-y in 1Q25), driven by steady growth in both corporate/retail loan book, up +0.54%/+0.73% q-q in 2Q25; solid loan growth of +1.9% q-q had outpaced deposit balance growth (+0.1% q-q in 2Q25), which led to an LDR increase by +1.59ppt q-q to 90.1% in 2Q25. Net fee income accelerated to +18.5% y-y in 2Q25 (vs. -4.6% y-y in 1Q25), to form 13.9% of total revenue (+0.8ppt y-y in 2Q25), likely backed by stronger-than-expected wealth mgmt. fee/consultancy fee income growth (+35%/+14% y-y in 1H25). Dealing gain surprised on a upside, surging notably by +3.1x q-q/+1.8x y-y to RMB27.7bn, which is an historic high, forming 13.7% of total revenue in 2Q25, +10.1ppt q-q/+8.2ppt y-y in 2Q, possibly backed by favorable bond market condition in 2Q25 and increased FX gain in 2Q. CIR was reduced modestly by -2ppt y-y to 25.6% in 2Q25 mainly thanks to revenue strength (+11.3% y-y in 2Q25) while manageable OPEX increase of +3.3% y-y also helped; CET-1/tier-1/total CAR were up +36bp/+52bp/+36bp q-q to 14.34%/15.19%/19.51% in 2Q25, mainly thanks to RMB105mn equity recapitalization in 2Q, which help boosted CCB's CET1 CAR by 45bp, based on 2Q25 RWA. Effective tax rate was down -2.65ppt y-y to 11.2% in 2Q25, likely thanks to increased government bond investment, which carries tax exemption (w/bond investment forming 26.6% of total assets in 2Q25, up 1.8ppt y-y). (Continue on P.2)
Price (29 Aug 25 16:10)HK$7.51Target priceHK$8.95Expected share price19.2%returnExpected dividend yield5.6%Expected total return24.8%Market CapHK$1,964,619MUS$252,078M

(RIC: 0939.HK, BB: 939 HK)

Citi Research is a division of Citigroup Global Markets Inc. (the "Firm"), which does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the Firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. Certain products (not inconsistent with the author's published research) are available only on Citi's portals.

Key Negatives — NIM was - 2bp q-q to \(1.39\%\) in 2Q25, due to lower asset yield (- 7bp q-q in 2Q per our est, likely dragged by ongoing loan book repricing) more than offsetting positive from lower funding cost (- 8bp q-q in 2Q by our est., likely thanks to past deposit rate cut bearing fruit). Asset quality was mixed. NPL ratio remains unchanged at \(1.33\%\) (flat q-q) in 2Q25, thanks to lower corporate NPL ratio (- 7bp h-h to \(1.58\%\) in 1H25, with broad-based NPL ratio reduction in most corporate sectors in 1H except for construction/utility sectors), more than offsetting the negative from higher retail NPL ratio (by +11bp h-h to \(1.10\%\) in 1H, driven by increase in mortgage/credit card loan NPL ratio, by +14bp/+13bp h-h to \(0.76\% /2.35\%\) in 1H25). However, after adding back write-offs, gross NPL formation rate was up +33bp q-q/+10bp y-y to \(0.62\%\) in 2Q25, likely due to increased NPL formation in the retail loan book. Of comfort, overdue >3-month loan ratio/SML ratio fell - 4bp/- 8bp h-h to \(0.96\% /1.81\%\) in 1H25, while NPL to overdue more-than-3mth loan ratio has picked up by +4.48ppt h-h to \(138.8\%\) in 1H25, indicating a tightened NPL recognition standard in 1H25. Against the increasing NPL formation trend, CCB charged a conservative credit cost of 88bp in 2Q25 (+14bp q-q/+25bp y-y), which helped drive up NPL coverage ratio to \(239.4\%\) in 2Q25 (+2.6ppt q-q).

Implications — While CCB's strong 2Q25 PPOP growth of \(14.4\%\) y-y in 2Q25 ranked second best among peers, thanks to record high trading gain in 2Q25, we note that CCB likely has taken the opportunity of still favorable macro backdrop in 2Q25 to pre- emptively stepped- up provision and build up NPL coverage (+2.6ppt q-q to \(239.4\%\) in 2Q25). This led to CCB's earnings growth of \(+1.6\%\) y-y in 2Q25 ranking only middle of the pack among Big6 banks in 2Q25 (compared to PSBC/ABC/BOCOM/ICBC/BOC 2Q25 earnings growth of \(+4.8\% / + 3.2\% / + 1.7\% / + 1.4\% / 1.0\%\) y-y in 2Q25). However, we do not hold it against the bank, as we see its pre- emptive/countercyclical provisioning practice could help better prepare the bank for potential NPL formation increase in 2H25, and create more room for provision release in 2H25E, to help bring CCB's 2025E fully- year NPAT growth to be at least flattish y-y (vs. CCB's 1H25 earnings decline of - \(1.4\%\) y-y does not rank well vs. Big6 bank peers in 1H). After factoring in the equity dilution of \(4.3\%\) from the recapitalization, we flag that CCB- A/- H 2025E dividend yield remains decent at \(4.2\% /5.4\%\) , ranking the highest/third highest among Big6 banks.
Figure 1. CCB 2Q25 result at a glance

China Construction Bank (CCB) is one of the Big Four state- owned banks in China, established in October 1954 and headquartered in Beijing. With over 14,000 branches and sub- branches nationwide, CCB has established an extensive footprint in the economically advanced regions - Yangtze River Delta, Pearl River Delta and Bohai Rim - as well as less- developed rural regions of Central, Western and Northeastern China. The extensive distribution network enables CCB to compete for large corporate customers on the capability of providing coordinated, nationwide services, and for retail customers on branch ubiquity.

We rate the CCB H- share at Buy. CCB's strong balance sheet, low risk profile (lowest risky loans and highest mortgage loan exposure among peers) and high profitability make it more resilient to the macro headwinds than its peers. As the bank with the highest loan exposure to mortgages and infrastructure loans, CCB is the key beneficiary from the recent strong credit growth to the two sectors and that should mean the bank's NPLs peak out ahead of its peers. Despite its low- risk profile, the bank has been conservative in NPL recognition as evidenced by it having the highest NPL to overdue \(>3m\) ratio (171% as of 2017). CCB enjoys above- peer profitability (the second highest ROA among our coverage), driven by the lowest funding cost and low CIR.

We use an Economic Value Added (EVA) model to determine our target price of HK\$8.95 for CCB H- shares. EVA is commonly used to value banks, especially when rate liberalization has kicked off and ROE is likely to drop. Our assumptions include a sustainable ROE of \(9\%\) and long- term growth of \(3\%\) . We adopt a cost of equity of \(14.8\%\) , which suggests a fair 2026E P/B of 0.57x.

Key downside risks that could mean the shares fail to achieve our EVA- based target price include: 1) more intense competition from private banks and online lenders; 2) higher- than- expected operation costs and funding costs; 3) negative impact from bank disintermediation; and 4) a weaker- than- expected macro economy.

We use an Economic Value Added (EVA) model to determine our target price of RMB11.4 for CCB A- shares. EVA is commonly used to value banks, especially when rate liberalization has kicked off and ROE is likely to drop. Our assumptions include a sustainable ROE of \(10\%\) and long- term growth of \(3\%\) . We adopt a cost of equity of \(11.4\%\) which suggests a fair FY26E P/B of \(0.8x\) .

Key downside risks that could mean the CCB A- shares fail to achieve our EVA- based target price include: 1) more intense competition from private banks and online lenders; 2) higher- than- expected operation costs and funding costs; 3) negative impact from bank disintermediation; and 4) weaker- than- expected macro economy.

Citi Research stock recommendations include an investment rating and an optional risk rating to highlight high risk stocks.Risk rating takes into account both price volatility and fundamental criteria. Stocks will either have no risk rating or a High risk rating assigned.

**Investment Ratings:** Citi Research investment ratings are Buy, Neutral and Sell. Our ratings are a function of analyst expectations of expected total return ("ETR") and risk. ETR is the sum of the forecast price appreciation (or depreciation) plus the dividend yield for a stock within the next 12 months. The target price is based on a 12 month time horizon. The Investment rating definitions are: Buy (1) ETR of 15% or more or 25% or more for High risk stocks; and Sell (3) for negative ETR. Any covered stock not assigned a Buy or a Sell is a Neutral (2). For stocks rated Neutral (2), if an analyst believes that there are insufficient valuation drivers and/or investment catalysts to derive a positive or negative investment view, they may elect with the approval of Citi Research management not to assign a target price and, thus, not derive an ETR. Citi Research may suspend its rating and target price and assign “Rating Suspended” status for regulatory and/or internal policy reasons. Citi Research may also suspend its rating and target price and assign "Under Review" status for other exceptional circumstances (e.g. lack of information critical to the analyst's thesis, trading suspension) affecting the company and/or trading in the company's securities. In both such situations, the rating and target price will show as “—“ and “-“ respectively in the rating history price chart. Prior to 11 April 2022 Citi Research assigned “Under Review” status to both situations and prior to 11 Nov 2020 only in exceptional circumstances. As soon as practically possible, the analyst will publish a note re-establishing a rating and investment thesis. Investment ratings are determined by the ranges described above at the time of initiation of coverage, a change in investment and/or risk rating, or a change in target price (subject to limited management discretion). At times, the expected total returns may fall outside of these ranges because of market price movements and/or other short-term volatility or trading patterns. Such interim deviations will be permitted but will become subject to review by Research Management.Your decision to buy or sell a security should be based upon your personal investment objectives and should be made only after evaluating the stock's expected performance and risk.

Catalyst Watch and STV Upside/Downside calls: Citi Research may also include a Catalyst Watch or STV Upside or Downside call to indicate the analyst expects the share price to rise (fall) in absolute terms over a specified period of 30 or 90 days in reaction to one or more specific near-term catalysts or events impacting the company or the market. A Catalyst Watch will be published when Analyst confidence is high that an impact to share price will occur; it will be a STV when confidence level is moderate. A Catalyst Watch or STV Upside/Downside call will automatically expire at the end of the specified 30/90 day period. The Catalyst Watch will also be automatically removed if share price performance (calculated at market close) exceeds 15% against the direction of the call (unless over-ridden by the analyst). The analyst may also remove a Catalyst Watch or STV call prior to the end of the specified period in a published research note. A Catalyst Watch/STV Upside or Downside call may be different from and does not affect a stock's fundamental equity rating, which reflects a longer-term total absolute return expectation. For purposes of FINRA ratings-distribution-disclosure rules, a Catalyst Watch/STV Upside call corresponds to a buy recommendation and a Catalyst Watch/STV Downside call corresponds to a sell recommendation. Any stock not assigned to a Catalyst Watch Upside, Catalyst Watch Downside, STV Upside, or STV Downside call is considered Catalyst Watch/STV No View. For purposes of FINRA ratings distribution-disclosure rules, we correspond Catalyst Watch/STV No View to Hold in our ratings distribution table for our Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside rating system. However, we reiterate that we do not consider No View to be a recommendation. For all Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside calls, risk exists that the catalyst(s) and associated share-price movement will not materialize as expected.
